items.title: [azure] blobfile fails to access container I have "Storage Blob Data Contributor" permissions to, through a group
items.body:
I'm part of a Group G that has access to storage account A, with the "Storage Blob Data Contributor" role.

I'm able to run `az storage blob list --account-name A -c [some_container]` with the az CLI, but blobfile fails to load:

`blobfile.BlobFile("https://A.blob.core.windows.net/some_container/...")`

fails with `blobfile.common.Error: Storage account ID not found for storage account: 'A'`

items.title: azure login mode
items.body:
It looks like there's no reliable way to detect if we can access a storage account, so we probably need `AZURE_STORAGE_AUTH_MODE` support in order to use key mode by default but allow users to select login mode.

The current check `_azure_can_access_account` returns true even if we can't read any of the containers because the permissions are wrong.

check if account can be accessed for service principals
items.body: the check used for cli creds should also be applied to service principals so we can raise an error about not having permission rather than a 403 exception

items.title: handle expired refresh tokens

items.title: "Storage account ID not found for storage account"
items.body: This error seems confusing

items.title: seems like _GoogleResumableUploadFailure can be returned to a user when using a streaming=True write file
Consider adding more checksum checking
items.body:
* Azure
  * Read: copy and readall() can check that the contents match the remote hash if it is available
  * Write: blocks can have md5s to verify their contents
* Google
  * Read: copy can check that the version we downloaded matches the remote hash, readall() could also check this
  * Write: when the object is finalized we could check the resulting md5 to see if it is what we thing it should be, a copy could be retried if it is not, though this could be problematic for multiple concurrent writers

Some of these checks could be done in apps instead of the library.

items.title: managing hashes and file modification times
items.body:
In order to implement rsync-like features, blobfile should provide a bit more functionality.

```
local files don't have md5 stored, so we have to use mtime to compensate by basically pretending it is a hash
alternatively, the user could keep a local hash cache and maybe avoid all this mtime business

def determine_action():
    # copy + update dst mtime + set dst md5
    # (which should happen automatically for remote files and cannot be done  for local files)
    if src_size != dst_size:
        return copy
    elif src_mtime != dst_mtime:
        if islocal(src) and islocal(dst):
            return copy

        if islocal(src):
            src_md5 = md5(src)
        if islocal(dst):
            dst_md5 = md5(dst)

        if (src_md5 is not None and dst_md5 is not None) and src_md5 == dst_md5:
            return set_mtime
        else:
            return copy
    else:
        return None
```


* `set_mtime(mtime, version=None)`
  * for azure/google files: set `blobfile-mtime` metadata field
    * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/set-blob-metadata
    * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/specifying-conditional-headers-for-blob-service-operations
    * If-Match
    * https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/json_api/v1/objects/patch
    * ifGenerationMatch
  * for local files: call `os.utime`
* `scandir()` should return the md5 if available, the `blobfile-mtime` if available (perhaps overwriting `mtime`), and the `version` (`etag` or `generation`)

<!--
* `set_md5(hash, tag=None)`
    * After we copy a file, we can update the md5 (from `return_md5=True`) of the src with this.  We will have the tag because we are using `scandir()`, and if our tag is stale this call will just fail and we can ignore it.  Doing this will avoid having to copy the src file if we have a local file with the correct contents but wrong mtime.
    * for azure, this will set the normal md5 header
    * for google, this may need to be an extra metadata field like `blobfile-md5`, since md5s are missing for composite objects, it should be an error to use this on an object that already has an md5 hash
    * for local files, ignore it

* for this to be useful, a large number of users would need the correct local file with the wrong mtime, this could happen if the src file was updated without changing the contents, but it's not clear that's worth setting the md5 just yet
-->

* issues
  * should be careful to avoid symlink loops: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33135038/how-do-i-use-os-scandir-to-return-direntry-objects-recursively-on-a-directory
  * how does copy ensure that the mtime is correct on the destination? seems like BlobFile would have to allow you to specify the mtime, or maybe return the version on close
  * how to handle azure blobs missing md5s

items.title: mtime/ctime seem to discard milliseconds
items.body:
`time.strptime` appears to discard milliseconds, try this instead:

```python
# google
t = datetime.datetime.strptime(text, "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f%z").timestamp()
# azure
t = datetime.datetime.strptime(text.replace("GMT", "Z"), "%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S %z").timestamp()
```

items.title: cache_dir with composite objects probably does not work
items.body: There's no test for this, and it looks like it will use the md5 to store the local file rather than the crc32.  So either it should update the md5 after downloading, or it should set a custom md5 field on the composite object to avoid future downloads.

items.title: azure block blobs error handling
items.body:
Should handle:

* put blocks block count limit (in case user goes over 50,000) blocks
* uncommitted block count limit
* concurrent writers - These should probably use unique random block id prefixes, without that the md5 could be wrong when the operation completes.  The first writer to finalize will then cause all uncommitted blocks to be deleted, presumably the other writers will fail during finalize.  It may make more sense to put an empty blob when opening the file, so as to delete all existing uncommitted blocks.  Without this, you could have a blob with 100k uncommitted blocks and no way to update it.  "If you write a block for a blob that does not exist, a new block blob is created, with a length of zero bytes." - so maybe just always removing any existing blob before writing the first block will suffice.

items.title: use block blobs instead of append blobs for azure
items.body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/understanding-block-blobs--append-blobs--and-page-blobs
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/put-block

"In version 2012-02-12 and newer, Put Blob sets a block blob’s MD5 hash value even when the Put Blob request doesn’t include an MD5 header."

items.title: should probably log on all failures rather than after the first one
items.body: The current behavior is a bit too confusing.

items.title: fallback to storage keys
items.body:
Service accounts should require a `AZURE_SUBSCRIPTION_ID` env var, so that we can fall back to reading storage account keys.

Also seems that keys should be the first thing to try and we should fallback to a normal oauth token, because there's no obvious way to guarantee that an oauth token will let us access a storage account.

items.body: This can happen even if the host does exist.  The account detection code may need to be more robust.

items.title: Proxyfile should cleanup during exception in close()
_StreamingReadFile should handle fork()
items.body: It seems likely that `_StreamingReadFile` can keep a connection open across a fork.  Should consider discarding the connection during a pid change, or else not keeping a persistent connection

items.title: weird close() behavior
items.body:
`close()` seems to fail sometimes when the interpreter is shutting down during `copy.copy()`, the exception can be seen if `__del__` is defined and calls `self.close()`.

```
f = bf.BlobFile("gs://my-bucket/test.txt", "wb")
f.write(b"meow")
```

```
Exception ignored in: <function _ProxyFile.__del__ at 0x103bd1d90>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 2452, in __del__
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 2438, in close
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 619, in copy
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 2263, in BlobFile
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 2016, in __init__
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 396, in _execute_google_api_request
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 403, in _execute_request
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 393, in build_req
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/google.py", line 150, in make_api_request
  File "/Users/csh/miniconda3/envs/procgen/lib/python3.7/copy.py", line 169, in deepcopy
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__newobj__'
```

Removing the use of copy fixes this, but it's not clear why:

```
return Request(
        method=req.method,
        url=req.url,
        params=params,
        headers=headers,
        data=data,
        preload_content=req.preload_content,
        success_codes=tuple(req.success_codes),
        retry_codes=tuple(req.retry_codes),
    )
```

  | (...)

It looks like ssl.SSLSocket has an fd of -1, is this due to running in a process pool executor and somehow not replacing the http pool manager?  This could also be a bug in urllib3.

items.body: Looks like this problem can occur when using application default credentials.  If it shows up again, blobfile should probably check some of these causes or print them out for users to try them: https://blog.timekit.io/google-oauth-invalid-grant-nightmare-and-how-to-fix-it-9f4efaf1da35

items.body: To make it more obvious that it's not meant to be exported

items.title: join can be a bit confusing
items.body:
```
In [23]: urllib.parse.urljoin("/testa/testb/", "2020-05-05T23-16:50-890294")
Out[23]: '2020-05-05T23-16:50-890294'
```

Seems like having ":" in the path is confusing to `urljoin`:

```
In [24]: urllib.parse.urlsplit("2020-05-05T23-16:50-890294")
Out[24]: SplitResult(scheme='2020-05-05t23-16', netloc='', path='50-890294', query='', fragment='')
```

The URL path can contain ":" https://stackoverflow.com/a/4669755

One possible workaround:

If `:` is in the path, replace it with a token value, join the paths, then replace the token value with `:`.

Might be useful to verify with a test that other characters are supported correctly.

items.title: add ability to disable/enable backends for BlobFile via environment variable
items.body: Maybe `BLOBFILE_DISABLE_BACKENDS=local,google,azure`

items.title: Consider making `bf.copy` also do `makedirs` for local destinations
items.body: analogously to #48

items.title: more paranoid read streaming
items.body: To be certain that the file offset cannot be advanced, https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/master/blobfile/ops.py#L1819 should reset the file on every error.

items.title: Significant performance regression in 0.16.2
items.body:
Using the following code, going from 0.16.1 to 0.16.2 the performance goes from 230+ files per second to about 5. I can only assume this is the [offending commit](https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/commit/4b929353be1220844e9a4309555904b29cc7a25b).

``` python
import blobfile as bf
from tqdm import tqdm
from queue import Queue
from threading import Thread

pending_queue = Queue()
done_queue = Queue()

def downloadEnclosures(in_queue, out_queue):
    while True:
        filename = in_queue.get()
        with bf.BlobFile(filename, "rb") as f:
            content = f.read()
            out_queue.put(content)
        in_queue.task_done()

for i in range(64):
    worker = Thread(target=downloadEnclosures, args=(pending_queue,done_queue))
    worker.setDaemon(True)
    worker.start()

filename = 'gs:/path/to/a/200kb.file'
for i in range(10000):
    pending_queue.put(filename)

for i in tqdm(range(10000)):
  done_queue.get()

```

items.title: error handling
items.body: `_execute_request` will retry on a number of errors, but will not retry if the error occurs while reading the response body.  For everything besides `_get_file` on `_StreamingReadFile`, this means that [`preload_content`](https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/f2bae6c761cd37ecf361288b6963f94c16a37d20/blobfile/ops.py#L413) should likely be set to `True`

items.title: make stub building opt-in
items.body: https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/master/setup.py#L67 should be hidden behind some env var or similar to avoid users accidentally running that

items.title: Configurable connection pool size
items.body:
Might improve efficiency in multi-threaded situations

* https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/master/blobfile/ops.py#L143
* https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/master/src/urllib3/poolmanager.py#L441
* https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/29b214a129883301f91ae4a74fd7ef2958cbf7b0/src/urllib3/connectionpool.py#L135

items.title: consider automatically making directories if they don't exist
items.body:
When creating a local file, intermediate directories are not created automatically.  This operates a bit differently on GCS, where intermediate directories are created implicitly when the file is created.

The main downside to changing this is that people could be surprised when local directories are created automatically (for instance, they have a typo in the directory name).  It's unclear if that's worth worrying about though since they would have this problem on GCS anyway.

This amounts to doing `bf.makedirs(bf.dirname(path))` when creating a `BlobFile` in write mode.

One downside is that opening a write mode remote file will do an extra network request.

items.title: Local cache for composite GCS objects
items.body:
BlobFile uses md5 hashes to handle local hashing.

`gsutil` uses composite objects to speed up uploads of large files. They do not have md5 hashes:
https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/composite-objects
>  Composite objects do not have an MD5 hash metadata field.

`bf.md5` will fail when passed such a file:
```
  File "/usr/local/miniconda3/envs/openai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 1602, in md5
    return base64.b64decode(metadata["md5Hash"]).hex()
KeyError: 'md5Hash'
```

An option would be to use CRC32, which is available for these files.

items.title: handle ssl.SSLError
items.body:
`urllib3` does not seem to handle `ssl.SSLError` correctly https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/1764, it should probably be caught in https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/9971e27e83a891ba7b832fa9e5d2f04bbcb1e65f/src/urllib3/response.py#L441 but as of python 3, https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html#ssl.SSLError is no longer a subtype of socket.error.

```
File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/blobfile/ops.py", line 1617, in readinto
    opt_n = self._f.readinto(b)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 661, in readinto
    temp = self.read(len(b))
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 507, in read
    data = self._fp.read(amt) if not fp_closed else b""
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/http/client.py", line 447, in read
    n = self.readinto(b)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/http/client.py", line 491, in readinto
    n = self.fp.readinto(b)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/socket.py", line 589, in readinto
    return self._sock.recv_into(b)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/ssl.py", line 1052, in recv_into
    return self.read(nbytes, buffer)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/ssl.py", line 911, in read
    return self._sslobj.read(len, buffer)
ssl.SSLError: [SSL: DECRYPTION_FAILED_OR_BAD_RECORD_MAC] decryption failed or bad record mac (_ssl.c:2488)
',)
```

It looks like `blobfile` will need to catch `ssl.SSLError` in https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/master/blobfile/ops.py#L386 and https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/master/blobfile/ops.py#L1676

items.title: make errors more obviously from blobfile
items.body: prefix messages with "blobfile": https://github.com/christopher-hesse/blobfile/blob/master/blobfile/ops.py#L147

items.title: exported type stubs are incorrect
items.body: Consider using `pyright --createstubs` instead, but then filtering the result to "public" symbols.  If that doesn't work, the `export-stubs.py` file can be fixed to correctly export classes.

items.title: bf.exists now raises an error
items.body:
For a non-existent bucket

It's interesting that the current tests don't cover this.

items.title: merge BlobFile and LocalBlobFile
items.body:
These were split to avoid confusion, but it seems like it's better to have a single interface that does the "correct" thing most of the time.  `BlobFile` but with a `streaming=DEFAULT_STREAMING` keyword argument.   Here are default values for streaming based on mode:

```
"r", "rb": streaming=True
"w", "wb": streaming=False
"a", "ab": streaming=False and assertion failure if streaming=True
```

`BlobFile` will return either a streaming or buffered file based on `streaming`.  It will be an error to set `cache_dir` for anything besides `mode="r", "rb"` and `streaming=False`.

`LocalBlobFile` can return `BlobFile` with `streaming=False`

items.title: use different format for azure urls
items.body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/storage?view=azure-cli-latest#az-storage-copy

`az storage copy` supports urls like `https://[account].blob.core.windows.net/[container]/[path/to/directory]`

items.title: write small files in a single request
items.body:
When uploading a single chunk smaller than `chunk_size` do this in a single request.  This also makes small files atomic so they can be retried even in streaming mode.

Benchmark this to verify that it's faster

items.title: handle 410 gone
items.body: https://github.com/googleapis/gcs-resumable-upload/issues/15#issuecomment-249324122

items.title: raise exceptions rather than assert for invalid status codes
items.body: Also make the url and method more obvious.

items.title: finish azure backend and update docs
items.body:
* [x] test azure backend with some production workloads
* [x] update docs to include information about azure backend

items.title: better glob support
items.body: Currently blobfile lists all objects matching the prefix of the pattern.  It would be better to only list matching directories using `delimiter`: https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/gsutil/addlhelp/WildcardNames#efficiency-consideration:-using-mid-path-wildcards

items.title: add mp.Pool example to docs
items.body: With tqdm and imap

items.title: spaces are not escaped correctly
items.body: in bf.exists() at least

items.title: feature request: make glob support multiple * operators
items.body: am curious what it would take to get this to work, at least on gcs!  (seems probably annoying, although gsutil supports this)

items.title: support gce metadata server for authentication
items.body: https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/access/create-enable-service-accounts-for-instances#applications

items.title: better warning if cache_dir does not exist
items.body: either create it or raise an exception

items.title: improve docs
items.body: it should be made more obvious that a streaming write file will only write large chunks and does not flush()

items.title: appendable file
items.body: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/platform/cloud/gcs_file_system.cc#L1064

items.title: document listdir behavior
items.body: / and generator

items.title: consider adding make_public() function
items.body: doesn't really do anything for local files but it's nice for remote ones

items.title: support azure environment variables
items.body: https://github.com/banzaicloud/azure-aks-client/blob/master/README.md#prerequisities

items.title: consider updating azure blob's md5 on each append rather than on close()
items.body: This would avoid having to calculate it when using `md5()`, but might slow down writing.

items.title: add static types
items.body:
* [x] switch to using [custom protocols](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/protocols.html#simple-user-defined-protocols) in `typings` directory
   * existing [BinaryIO type](https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.BinaryIO) returns a union of str and byte in readlines which seems to prevent handling the return value correctly while typeshed seems to just be wrong a bunch
   * It's unclear if custom protocols can be used with python 3.6, maybe if I keep the pyi files separate
* [x] remove custom typeshed if possible
* [x] add types for all blobfile functions
* [x] [add types for external library functions](https://github.com/microsoft/pyright/blob/master/docs/type-stubs.md)
  * [x] some old ones for urllib3: https://github.com/python/typeshed/tree/master/third_party/2and3/requests/packages/urllib3
* [x] enable strict mode
* [x] indicate that type information is present https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installed_packages.html

See also https://github.com/microsoft/pyright/blob/master/docs/getting-started.md

items.title: md5 on azure is not guaranteed to work
items.body:
Falling back to a different cache key could be useful, but it means when we download a file, we don't know what key to use to store it since the file may have changed and it's unclear if we downloaded only the original data or the new data.

One option would be to calculate the MD5 and update it on the blob, this would be slow the first time but fast on subsequent calls as long as the file is not being modified. 

To avoid race conditions, it looks like Set Blob Properties can use `If-Match` on the `ETag` value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/specifying-conditional-headers-for-blob-service-operations and then ignore a failure due to the object being updated.

It may also be a good idea to remove `cache_key` since this function doesn't seem useful.

items.title: token expiration
items.body: Tokens should be discarded a bit before their actual expiration.  In addition, requests should get a new token on each retry.

items.title: fork safety
items.body: urllib3 and the ssl context do not appear to be fork safe, add fork protection: https://github.com/cshesse/blobfile/blob/2fd9c2c4ef750c03a9aed1fdaea9961d16bda9ed/blobfile/blobfile.py#L65
